skill.name: desmos-graphing
skill.description: Create interactive Desmos graphs in Obsidian using desmos-graph code blocks. Use when visualizing functions, parametric curves, inequalities, or mathematical relationships with customizable styling and settings.
skill.summary: Create interactive Desmos graphs in Obsidian using desmos-graph code blocks. Use when visualizing fu...
skill.author: BitYoungjae

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown documentation explaining Desmos graph syntax. Static findings are false positives from markdown code formatting (backticks) and LaTeX math notation being misinterpreted as security issues.

content.user_title: Create Desmos mathematical graphs in Obsidian
content.value_statement: Creating mathematical graphs for documentation is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides complete reference syntax for rendering interactive Desmos graphs directly in Obsidian markdown using desmos-graph code blocks with full styling and customization support.
actual_capabilities: Create function graphs with y=f(x) syntax
Apply colors, line styles, and restrictions
Configure graph viewport and axis settings
limitations: Cannot render graphs directly (requires obsidian-desmos plugin)
Does not provide interactive graph editing
No built-in formula solving or calculation

use_cases.title: Visualize math concepts
use_cases.description: Create graphs of functions, trig curves, and equations to illustrate mathematical concepts in study notes.

use_cases.title: Build interactive lessons
use_cases.description: Design educational content with labeled points, multiple curves, and annotations for classroom materials.

use_cases.title: Document mathematical models
use_cases.description: Include professional graphs in technical documentation showing relationships, constraints, and solutions.

prompt_templates.title: Basic sine wave
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a desmos-graph code block showing y=sin(x) and y=cos(x) on the same plot from -2Ï€ to 2Ï€.

prompt_templates.title: Labeled points
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a desmos-graph with a circle xÂ²+yÂ²=25 and mark the point (3,4) with label 'Point A'.

prompt_templates.title: Trigonometric identities

prompt_templates.title: Piecewise function
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a piecewise function graph that shows y={x<0: -x, x>=0: âˆšx} with the junction point labeled.

output: âœ“ Graph rendered with parabola (blue) and line (red)

output: âœ“ Rose curve (3 petals) displayed in blue
âœ“ Spiral curve from origin displayed in red

best_practices: Use \pi (LaTeX) in equations and points, but pi (mathjs) in settings
Apply restrictions with plain math only - no LaTeX commands like \sqrt
Separate settings from equations with --- on its own line
Use hex colors for gray, pink, brown and other unsupported names
anti_patterns: Using | in labels (causes parsing errors - use Unicode âˆ¥ instead)
Mixing LaTeX \sqrt in restrictions (use x^0.5 instead)
Putting multiple --- separators in one code block
Using rÂ² or rÂ³ in polar equations (convert to parametric form)

faq.question: Which colors are supported in desmos-graph?
faq.answer: Only 10 colors by name: red, green, blue, yellow, orange, purple, cyan, magenta, black, white. Use hex codes for gray, pink, brown.

faq.question: What is the difference between pi and \pi?
faq.answer: Use pi in settings (mathjs syntax) and \pi in equations and points (LaTeX). This is the most common source of errors.

faq.question: Can I use Desmos sliders in Obsidian?
faq.answer: Yes, define variables like a=2 and b=3, then use them in equations. Sliders will appear in the rendered graph.

faq.question: How do I limit where a curve is drawn?
faq.answer: Add restrictions after | using plain math: y=xÂ²|0<x<5. Use ^0.5 for square root, numeric values for Ï€.

faq.question: Is my data safe when rendering graphs?
faq.answer: Yes, graphs are rendered locally by the obsidian-desmos plugin. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: How does this compare to Mermaid or TikZ?
faq.answer: Desmos provides fully interactive graphs with zoom, pan, and sliders. Mermaid is simpler but less interactive. TikZ offers more control but requires LaTeX knowledge.
